I Have played through this game more than 50 times I Love it. always fun trying things that was no so posed to happen in the game go places you should not go .  Time to play it again.

Half life 2 se ubica 20 años después primer juego donde  Freeman aceptó trabajar para G-Man tras derrotar a Nihilanth, después de esto quedo en un estado de hibernación, en ese tiempo mientras Freeman  estaba  congelado en el tiempo,  la alianza derroto a la humanidad en la guerra de las 7 horas y nombraron al Dr. Wallace Breen (el antiguo director de Black Mesa) como administrador de la tierra, ya que aparentemente el ayudo a la alianza a ganar la guerra, G-Man saca a Gordon de su estado de hibernación para hacerle frente a la Alianza e intentar sacar a la Humanidad de la situación en la que está metida.

[h1]Al finalizar este juego la continuación directa son los Episode One and Two  en los cuales no concluye la historia, pero aporta más información de lo que paso con Alyx y Freeman después del final del Half life 2. [/h1]

El juego en si es un FPS en el cual encarnamos a Freeman es vez más con el objetivo de detener los planes de Wallace, en si es un juego lineal donde los mapas en ciertas partes tienden a ser repetitivos  donde te atacan oleadas de enemigos y solamente te abres paso sobre ellos,  la variedad de enemigos no es muy extensa ya que solo hay 4 clases de enemigos que son los solados de la Alianza, vehículos, los insectos y los  zombies,  en cuanto a las armas hay mucha variedad pero en su mayoría solo encuentras munición de las armas principales (pistola, metralletas y escopeta) ya que son las que recoges de los enemigos, estos enemigos tienen una inteligencia moderada ya que se reposicionan si sufren daño y se cubren.
En varias partes del juego el juego intenta meter otro tipo de mecánicas  para evitar que se sienta repetitivo ejemplo: Uso del carro, Lancha, Oleadas de enemigos (defender un punto o persona), parkour y batallas contra vehículos o insectos grandes (como si fueran pequeños jefes).

Lo único que no me llego a gustar es el manejo de los vehículos, los personajes que se te unen como pelotón te estorban en lugares pequeños provocando que en ocasiones te puedan matar (principalmente me paso en el nivel de la mansión) y por último que no te indiquen por donde continuar la misión  provocando en ocasiones que estés dando vueltas para identificar a donde te debes dirigir para continuar.

Half-Life 2,
Легенда игровой индустрии? Вполне возможно.
Сюжет.
Это уникальная и оригинальная история.
Большое количество загадок.
В целом, нужно отметить, что он просто интересный.

Геймплей.
Во-первых, затягивает своей простотой. Это очень похоже на сюжетный Counter-Strike.
Во-вторых, он построен таким образом, что как только вам начинает надоедать какая-либо сюжетная механика, сразу на её замену приходит другая. Из этого и состоит +- 10 часовой сюжет данной игры.
В совокупности, конечно и со всей историей half-life, в игре правда очень классный сюжет.

Тем не менее, half-life 2 - это не цельный продукт, и он имеет два сиквела ( episode 1 и 2 ), которые нуждаются в отдельной оценке.
Игра-легенда, без нареканий.
uma obra prima, simplismente incrivel, mecânica do jogo é sensacional, os gráficos são bem bonitos. Simplismente um dos melhores FPS que já joguei ou ouvi falar na minha vida.

Half-Life 2 is a 2004 first-person shooter game developed and published by Valve. Like the original Half-Life, it combines shooting, puzzles, and storytelling, and adds features such as vehicles and physics-based gameplay. Players control Gordon Freeman, who fights the alien Combine with allies including resistance fighter Alyx Vance, using weapons such as the object-manipulating gravity gun.

The game was created using Valve's Source engine, developed alongside. Development lasted five years and cost US$40 million. Valve president Gabe Newell set his team the goal of redefining the FPS genre, focusing on advanced physics systems and non-player characters. Valve announced Half-Life 2 at E3 2003 and released it through its new distribution service Steam after delaying it by over a year. A year before release, a hacker stole an unfinished version and leaked it online.

Half-Life 2 received acclaim for its advanced physics, animation, sound, AI, graphics, and narrative. It won 39 Game of the Year awards, and has been cited as one of the greatest games of all time. By 2011, it had sold 12 million copies. It was followed by the episodic sequels Episode One (2006) and Episode Two (2007). A prequel, Half-Life: Alyx, was released in 2020.

Like the original Half-Life (1998), Half-Life 2 is a single-player first-person shooter in which players control Gordon Freeman. It has similar mechanics to Half-Life, including health-and-weapon systems and periodic physics puzzles, except with the newer Source engine and improved graphics. The player also starts without items, slowly building up their arsenal over the course of the game. Despite the game's mainly linear nature, much effort was put into making exploration rewarding and interesting; many optional areas can be missed or avoided.

A diverse set of enemies is present, which usually require being approached with different tactics: some coordinate in groups to out-maneuver or out-position the player; others, such as the Manhack, fly directly at the player through small openings and tight corridors. Others use predictable but powerful attacks, while others hide before swiftly attacking the player. Gordon can kill most enemies with his weapons, or make use of indirect means, exploiting environmental hazards such as explosive pressurized canisters, gas fires or improvised traps. For some portions of the game, Gordon can be joined by up to four armed Resistance soldiers or medics and can send his team further from him or call them back.

Many of the game's new features utilize its detailed physics simulation. Two sections of the game involve driving vehicles. Instead of button-oriented puzzles from Half-Life, environmental puzzles are also introduced with makeshift mechanical systems, revolving around the player's new ability to pick up, move, and place objects. Solutions involve objects' physical properties, such as shape, weight, and buoyancy. For example; In chapter three, "Route Kanal", the player is required to stack cinder blocks on a makeshift see-saw ramp to proceed over a wall. Alternatively, the player can build a crude staircase with the blocks, so the puzzle may be solved in multiple ways.

Part-way through the game, Gordon acquires the Gravity Gun, which allows him to draw distant objects towards himself or forcefully push them away, as well as the ability to manipulate larger and heavier objects that he cannot control without the weapon. These abilities are required to solve puzzles later in the game, and can also be used to great effect in combat, as any non-static object within proximity to the player has the potential to be used as a makeshift defense, such as a file cabinet, or a deadly projectile, such as a gasoline can or buzzsaw blade.

The game never separates the player with pre-rendered cutscenes or events; the story proceeds via exposition from other characters and in-world events, and the player can control Gordon for the entirety of the game. Much of the backstory to the game is simply alluded to or told through the environment.

Dr. Gordon Freeman is the main protagonist of the Half-Life series. Freeman is a theoretical physicist, forced to defend himself and the human race in a conflict against hostile aliens and other enemies after a failed experiment causes a worldwide alien invasion.

In the process, Freeman becomes an almost legendary resistance hero, eventually rising to be one of the key leaders in the war against an inter-dimensional empire.



Alyx Vance is the deuteragonist of Half-Life 2 and its Episodes and the titular protagonist of Half-Life: Alyx. A woman in her mid-twenties, she is a prominent figure in the Resistance campaign against the rule of the Combine.

Dr. Eli Vance is a former Black Mesa researcher and physicist. Decades after the failed experiment, he has become one of the key leaders in a fight against the Combine’s totalitarian rule. He wears a prosthetic leg to replace his left leg beneath the knees.

Dr. Isaac Kleiner is a scientist and one of the main characters of Half-Life 2 and its episodes. An archetypal 'absent-minded genius scientist' (although somewhat more benign), he is a prolific author of several works on teleportation and interdimensional travel, and one of the few survivors of the incident that took place in the Black Mesa Research Facility. Later on, he becomes a key (if somewhat self-conscious) leader of the Resistance against the Combine, and a prime member of the Resistance science team.



"We should thank our benefactors for giving us respite from this overpowering force. They have thrown a switch and exorcised our demons in a single stroke. They have given us the strength we never could have summoned to overcome this compulsion. They have given us purpose. They have turned our eyes toward the stars."
Wallace Breen, addressing citizens' concerns about the Combine negating human reproduction.

Я буду краток, и, возможно, не очень объективен, но Half-life 2 одна из моих любимых игр. Все же это первый мой серьезный шутер. И пускай много что уже сказано про нее (76 тысяч обзоров не дадут соврать), мне все же есть что сказать.

Я уже не раз проходил эту игру, а также и все остальные игры серии (нет, я не устал), и даже когда в моем распоряжении будет железо мощнее, я еще не раз и не два зайду сюда снова. Почему? Да, впрочем ничего такого, это просто отличная игра, которая пробуждает во мне настальгические чувства. Типо, она отлично сделана даже по сегодняшним меркам. Поэтому я просто расскажу как впервые с ней познакомился.

Мой папа показал как в нее играть, после чего рассказал про чит-коды на оружие. Я просто бегал по вокзалу сити-17 и валил ГО-шников. Эх, были времена. Ну а потом я узнал что у нее оказывается есть сюжет, еще два эпизода, а также, О МОЙ БОГ, первая часть! В КОТОРОЙ ВОРТИГОНТЫ ЯВЛЯЮТСЯ ВРАГАМИ (серьезно, это было первое, чему я был поражен, когда отец рассказывал мне о ней)! Это же так круто! Меня тогда ничуть не смутила разница в графике, и, по правде говоря, в какой-то степени первая часть мне нравиться даже больше, но тем не менее.

Как то так. Не вижу смысла писать больше, это просто маленькая история из жизни тогда еще молодого меня) Рекомендую ли я? Безусловно.

Aaaaand now I know why everyone wants a Half-Life 3. Keep hoping, people, Valve can't hold out on us forever!

[h1] Introduction/Disclaimers [/h1]

This is a relatively spoiler-free review. There will be no mentions of what happens story-wise, but I will talk about game mechanics, weapon varieties and the new weapon introduced, and level layouts. I will also discuss the quality of the story, but I'll make sure not to spoil the story itself. If you consider these to be spoilers, read at your own risk. If not, yay!

I'll also discuss the first Half-Life game, which I played the Source remake of, and Half-Life 2: Episodes 1 and 2.

If you've never heard of the Half-Life series, you're probably new to either Steam or the internet itself, what with the highly-anticipated launch of Half-Life: Alyx not too long ago. The series holds some of the earliest FPS games around that have gameplay that can reasonably hold up against the test of time--graphics are another story, but you can't expect too much from a series over a decade old.

Now, these games are made in chronological order, with Half-Life Alyx being the only exception. The order of the main storyline is Half-Life, Half-Life 2, and Half-Life 2 Episodes 1 and 2.

Now here comes the disclaimer, and the reason I can't recommend this series wholeheartedly...

[b] Disclaimer:[/b] The story of this series [i] does not have a conclusion as of summer 2020. [/i] And, yes, the most recent installment was released in 2007, almost 13 years ago.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

It's a shooter. You shoot things. Lots of things.

Well, not quite. Your first weapon is the good 'ol crowbar, handy for whacking planks off of boarded up doorways and good for your general bludgeoning needs. Similar to the original Half-Life, you pick up guns and more powerful weapons as you progress through the game. The most notable difference in weaponry is that you have little to no access to the alien weapons that were abundant in the first game. Personally, I enjoyed the variety the alien weapons gave me, but it makes sense story-wise.

The level layouts are pretty open, similar to those of Doom (2016), which gives the game more of an open-world vibe. I recall in the original Half-Life that you could return to earlier levels simply by walking back the way you came. You can't do that very much in Half-Life 2, with drops and blockades making previous areas inaccessible, but it still has an open feel to it.

The biggest thing that distinguishes this FPS game from the rest is the introduction of the Gravity Gun, which allows you to move extremely heavy objects and move and throw lighter objects extreme distances. Now, I've never found "pure" FPS games (e.g. Call of Duty) to be notably fun, but the Gravity Gun makes this one of my favorite shooter games. You can kill enemies by shooting heavy items at them. You get an achievement if you kill someone with a toilet, for example. You can pick up sawblades and fire them at a group, taking down several enemies at once. You can carry crates and other objects to use as shields. You can shoot explode-y barrels at your enemies, just be quick about it if they're actively shooting you.

And the achievements. Holy cow, if you're a completionist, this game is going to make you work for it.

There's the typical achievements you get with completing chapters and certain areas, just make sure you're logged into Steam otherwise they won't register (which is why I only have half the achievements...). There's an achievement you can get for completing an entire area by only using the Gravity Gun as your weapon. Luckily there's a lot of sawblades laying around, but that area is [i] spooky. [/i] There's an achievement where you have to find 40-odd secret caches of ammo in the game. Now, obviously for this one you could just look it up, but where's the fun in that?

[h1] Game Mechanics [/h1]

Puzzles are a recurring theme in the series, another aspect that sets it apart from other FPS games. These puzzles usually include the environment, which either must be navigated through or around. You might have to crawl through that vent to get around that fence, or maybe you can just stack some boxes on top of that car and jump it. Do you really want to try to parkour through that minefield, or can you just back away and throw a barrel at them? It's up to you.

The physics in the series is pretty neat. Now, with this being a game made well over a decade ago, it's not what you would consider "realistic." That means that, when the physics break every once in a while, it's more amusing than immersion-breaking. Personally, I love the ragdoll physics that are in this series, and I don't really mind when things break physics-wise because it's entertaining. Another neat thing is that nearly every object is interactable. You can hold a health pack if your health is full, meaning you can stockpile them when there's an area you have to defend or otherwise stay in for a while.

Just keep in mind that, when everything is interactable, you can accidentally kill yourself by shooting something up in the air or at a wall and it hits you at high speed. Don't forget to save your game!

[h1] Story [/h1]

The Half-Life series is unique here. In the entire series, I can only think of one scene that can be truly considered a cutscene--and even then, it's an opening sequence. Since cutscenes aren't a thing, major events and whatnot are scheduled or triggered by characters' actions, including your own. The rest of the time, you can literally just wander around the room while other characters are discussing what's happening. But if you care about the story, you might as well stick around and listen...

The Half-Life series has a fascinating story concept that they executed very well. Or more accurately, that they [i] almost [/i] executed well.

You see, there's a problem. The story isn't complete, and where it leaves off is nowhere near a place I would consider a satisfying ending. This is the greatest flaw of the series, and the reason why I can't wholeheartedly recommend it.

The gameplay is great, and I would consider to be a must-play series if that were the focus. But the gameplay is deeply integrated and intertwined with the story, and one without the other simply wouldn't hold the same experience. That's why it's so disappointing that the series never came to a conclusion.

Now, if you were to play this series primarily for the story, I would recommend playing Half-Life 1 and 2. That's it. Trust me, it's a better option than playing the episodes and knowing where that story ends unfinished.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Overall, I enjoyed this series. But the fact that it was abandoned with no explanation feels like an absolute betrayal. They never even publicly confirmed whether Half-Life 3--or Half-Life 2 Episode 3, or whatever they're calling the next chapter--was officially cancelled. I'd rather get an official notice that they're cancelling the game and the story is finished, rather than radio silence for another 13 years.

If or when they release Half-Life 3, I think a total remaster of the entire series would make an excellent apology for making everyone wait so long for the conclusion of the story.

I can't wholeheartedly recommend this series, but I can't say it's completely bad, either. My advice, if you want to try it, would be to play the first Half-Life and see what you think before moving forward.

Some pros of this game are:

- Great story 

- Amazing characters

- Enemies to fight are somewhat challenging

- A engine of its own and birthed a ton of games like Garry's Mod and Left 4 Dead

-  Awesome arsenal of weapons

Now for some cons:

-  Glitches that Valve does not really fix

Those are the only cons I can think of! This game is a 9/10

Half-Life 2 was the game that I played when I was younger but now when I've came back to it I still find new things that I didn't discover when I was younger and I enjoy this game to the very limits it gives.

Easily the best FPS ever created in my opinion. It is one of the few games I would ever feel comfortable giving a 100% to, because I cant even think of a single bad part of the game or an area that it doesn't get perfect. It is also the perfect length for this type of game. Not too long, but not too short either. Its simply a Masterpiece and my personal favorite FPS game ever only rivaled by Halo 3 in which Half Life 2 still comes out on top for me (both are great) but this game is just simply perfect. Nothing about this game doesn't work, in other words everything it does it does insanely well and I would even say it does most of it if not all of it perfectly. A rare type of game, and something every person on Earth that enjoys video games must experience. 10/10
